CREATURE.name: ghost
CREATURE.significance: The central character, attempting to scare the Otis family.

CREATURE.name: Dowager Duchess of Bolton
CREATURE.description: A member of the Canterville family
CREATURE.significance: Frightened by the ghost, setting the stage for the story.

CREATURE.name: skeleton
CREATURE.significance: A manifestation of the ghost's presence.

CREATURE.name: Lady Eleanore de Canterville
CREATURE.significance: Her blood stain is a key element of the ghost's haunting.

CREATURE.name: Sir Simon de Canterville
CREATURE.significance: The main character, a ghost haunting Canterville Chase.

CREATURE.name: Red Ruben, or the Strangled Babe
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: Gaunt Gibeon, the Blood - sucker of Bexley Moor
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: Dumb Daniel, or the Suicide's Skeleton
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: Black Isaac, or the Huntsman of Hogley Woods
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: Reckless Rupert, or the Headless Earl
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: The Vampire Monk, or, the Bloodless Benedictine
CREATURE.significance: One of the ghost's past performances.

CREATURE.name: Angel of Death
CREATURE.significance: Virginia asks for mercy from the Angel of Death for the ghost.

ITEM.name: skeleton hands
ITEM.description: Two skeleton hands placed on the Dowager Duchess of Bolton's shoulders.
ITEM.origin: Used by the ghost to frighten the Dowager Duchess of Bolton.

ITEM.name: chains
ITEM.description: Heavy manacles and rusty gyves worn by the ghost.
ITEM.origin: Part of the ghost's appearance.

ITEM.name: Tammany Rising Sun Lubricator
ITEM.origin: Given to the ghost by Mr. Otis to oil his chains.

ITEM.name: pillow
ITEM.description: A large pillow thrown at the ghost.
ITEM.origin: Thrown by the twins at the ghost.

ITEM.name: suit of armour
ITEM.description: A large suit of old armour.
ITEM.origin: The ghost's attempt to frighten the family.

ITEM.name: peashooters
ITEM.origin: Used by the twins to shoot the ghost.

ITEM.name: revolver
ITEM.origin: Used by the United States Minister to threaten the ghost.

ITEM.name: candle
ITEM.origin: Extinguished by the ghost.

ITEM.name: Dr. Dobell's tincture
ITEM.description: A bottle of Dr. Dobell's tincture.
ITEM.origin: Offered to the ghost by Mrs. Otis.

ITEM.name: winding-sheet
ITEM.description: A long shroud spotted with churchyard mould.
ITEM.origin: Worn by the ghost in his impersonation of 'Jonas the Graveless'.

ITEM.name: arquebuse
ITEM.origin: Carried by the ghost.

ITEM.name: dagger
ITEM.origin: Carried by the ghost.

ITEM.name: lantern
ITEM.origin: Carried by the ghost.

ITEM.name: sexton's spade
ITEM.origin: Carried by the ghost.

ITEM.name: garden-syringe
ITEM.origin: Used by Washington Otis to scare the ghost.

ITEM.name: box of jewels
ITEM.origin: Given to Virginia by the ghost.

ITEM.name: ruby necklace
ITEM.description: A ruby necklace with old Venetian setting.
ITEM.origin: Part of the jewels given to Virginia by the ghost.

ITEM.name: cross
ITEM.description: A large cross made of white and pink almond-blossoms.
ITEM.origin: Placed on the coffin by Virginia.

ITEM.name: coronet
ITEM.origin: The reward of all good little American girls.

ITEM.name: paint
ITEM.origin: Stolen by the ghost to furbish up the blood-stain.

ITEM.name: blood-stain
ITEM.description: A dull red stain on the library floor.
ITEM.origin: The blood of Lady Eleanore de Canterville.

ITEM.name: gold
ITEM.description: The gold of the yellow trees.
ITEM.origin: The gold of the yellow trees.

ITEM.name: red leaves
ITEM.description: The red leaves dancing madly down the long avenue.
ITEM.origin: The red leaves dancing madly down the long avenue.

ITEM.name: tombstone
ITEM.origin: The tombstone of Sir Simon.

ITEM.name: cigarette
ITEM.origin: The cigarette of the Duke.

EVENT.name: Mr. Otis buys Canterville Chase
EVENT.summary: Mr. Hiram B. Otis, the American minister, purchases Canterville Chase, despite warnings that it is haunted.

EVENT.name: The Otis family arrives at Canterville Chase
EVENT.summary: The Otis family arrives at Canterville Chase and is greeted by Mrs. Umney, the housekeeper.

EVENT.name: The bloodstain is discovered
EVENT.summary: Mrs. Otis notices a bloodstain in the library, and Mrs. Umney explains its origin as the blood of Lady Eleanore de Canterville.

EVENT.name: Washington Otis removes the bloodstain
EVENT.summary: Washington Otis removes the bloodstain with Pinkerton's Champion Stain Remover, causing a storm and Mrs. Umney to faint.

EVENT.name: The bloodstain reappears
EVENT.summary: The bloodstain reappears the next morning, and the family becomes intrigued by its persistence.

EVENT.name: The ghost appears to Mr. Otis
EVENT.summary: The ghost appears to Mr. Otis in the corridor, who offers him a bottle of lubricating oil.

EVENT.name: The ghost is humiliated
EVENT.summary: The ghost is humiliated by the Otis family's reactions to his attempts to scare them, including being offered lubricant and having pillows thrown at him.

EVENT.name: The ghost's second attempt
EVENT.summary: The ghost attempts to scare the family again, but the twins shoot him with peashooters, and Mrs. Otis offers him medicine.

EVENT.name: The ghost's third attempt
EVENT.summary: The ghost plans a third attempt, but is frightened by a ghost-like figure and flees.

EVENT.name: The ghost is tricked
EVENT.summary: The ghost is tricked by the twins, who set up a fake ghost to scare him.

EVENT.name: Virginia meets the ghost
EVENT.summary: Virginia meets the ghost in the Tapestry Chamber and pities him.

EVENT.name: Virginia helps the ghost
EVENT.summary: Virginia agrees to help the ghost find peace by praying for him and fulfilling the prophecy.

EVENT.name: Virginia disappears
EVENT.summary: Virginia disappears, causing the family to search for her.

EVENT.name: Virginia reappears
EVENT.summary: Virginia reappears, revealing that she has been with the ghost and that he is dead.

EVENT.name: The ghost's remains are found
EVENT.summary: The family finds the ghost's remains in a secret room, and Virginia reveals the jewels he gave her.

EVENT.name: The ghost is buried
EVENT.summary: The ghost is given a proper burial in the churchyard.

EVENT.name: Virginia's marriage
EVENT.summary: Virginia marries the Duke of Cheshire.

EVENT.name: The Duke and Duchess visit the grave
EVENT.summary: The Duke and Duchess visit the ghost's grave, and Virginia reveals that she will never tell anyone what happened to her when she was locked up with the ghost.

CHAPTER.title: CHAPTER I
CHAPTER.summary: Mr. Otis, the American minister, buys Canterville Chase, a haunted house. Lord Canterville warns him about the ghost, but Otis dismisses it. The Otis family moves in, encountering the bloodstain and Mrs. Umney's warnings. Washington Otis removes the bloodstain with a cleaner, leading to a storm and Mrs. Umney's distress.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  II
CHAPTER.summary: The bloodstain reappears, and the Otis family becomes intrigued. The ghost, Sir Simon, attempts to scare Mr. Otis, but is thwarted by the offer of lubricant. He is further humiliated by the twins' pranks and retreats, vowing revenge.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  III
CHAPTER.summary: The Otis family discusses the ghost. The bloodstain changes colors, amusing the family except Virginia. The ghost attempts to scare them again, but is met with more pranks and medical remedies. He is defeated and resolves to try again.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  IV
CHAPTER.summary: The ghost is exhausted and considers giving up. He is further humiliated by the twins' pranks and decides to make a final effort as 'Reckless Rupert.' He fails again, and is defeated by the twins and the garden syringe. He is now an invalid.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  V
CHAPTER.summary: Virginia encounters the ghost in the Tapestry Chamber. She pities him and learns about his desire for rest. She agrees to help him find peace by fulfilling the prophecy on the library window. She enters a dark portal with the ghost.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  VI
CHAPTER.summary: Virginia disappears, causing panic. The family searches for her, including the Duke of Cheshire. Virginia is found, revealing she was with the ghost, who is now dead. They discover his skeleton and the blossoming almond tree, signifying his forgiveness.

CHAPTER.title: C H A P T E R  VII
CHAPTER.summary: The ghost is buried with a proper funeral. Lord Canterville allows Virginia to keep the jewels. Virginia marries the Duke of Cheshire. They visit the grave and Virginia reveals she will never tell the secret of what happened with the ghost.

ORGANIZATION.name: Psychical Society
ORGANIZATION.description: An organization that Mrs. Otis expresses her intention of joining.
ORGANIZATION.significance: Indicates Mrs. Otis's interest in the supernatural.

ORGANIZATION.name: Free American Reformed Episcopalian Church
ORGANIZATION.description: The church whose simple rites the Otis family follows.

ORGANIZATION.name: Democratic Party
ORGANIZATION.description: The political party Mr. Otis is writing a history of.
ORGANIZATION.significance: Reflects Mr. Otis's political interests and values.

CHARACTER.name: Oscar Wilde
CHARACTER.description: Author of the story.

CHARACTER.name: Virginia E. Otis

CHARACTER.name: Duke of Cheshire

CHARACTER.name: The Twins
CHARACTER.description: The twin sons of the Otis family.

CHARACTER.name: Mrs. Umney
CHARACTER.description: The housekeeper of Canterville Chase.

CHARACTER.name: Lady Eleanore de Canterville
CHARACTER.description: The murdered wife of Sir Simon de Canterville.

CHARACTER.name: Sir Simon de Canterville
CHARACTER.description: The ghost of Canterville Chase.

CHARACTER.name: Miss Fanny Davenport
CHARACTER.description: An actress.

CHARACTER.name: Sarah Bernhardt
CHARACTER.description: An actress.

CHARACTER.name: Lord Raker
CHARACTER.description: A person whose wig turned grey from the ghost's laughter.

CHARACTER.name: Hon. Thomas Horton
CHARACTER.description: Lord Canterville's uncle.

CHARACTER.name: Lord Canterville's grandfather
CHARACTER.description: The grandfather of the current Lord Canterville.

CHARACTER.name: Lady Barbara Modish
CHARACTER.description: A lady who broke off her engagement with Lord Canterville's grandfather.

CHARACTER.name: Jack Castleton
CHARACTER.description: Lady Barbara Modish's lover.

CHARACTER.name: Lord Rufford
CHARACTER.description: The Cantervilles' neighbor.

CHARACTER.name: Lord Francis Stilton

CHARACTER.name: Old Lady Startup
CHARACTER.description: A lady who died after seeing the Vampire Monk.

CHARACTER.name: Colonel Carbury
CHARACTER.description: A person who bet with Lord Francis Stilton.

CHARACTER.name: Sieur de Bulkeley
CHARACTER.description: Sir Simon's cousin's husband.

CHARACTER.name: Marchioness of Dumbleton
CHARACTER.description: A noble woman who wanted to marry her daughter to the Duke.

LOCATION.name: Canterville Chase
LOCATION.description: Canterville Chase is a large, old castle in England. It is the primary setting of the story and is known for being haunted. The Otis family moves into the castle, and the ghost of Sir Simon de Canterville attempts to scare them.
LOCATION.significance: The main setting where the majority of the story takes place. It is the home of the Canterville Ghost and the Otis family.

LOCATION.name: West 53rd Street
LOCATION.description: This is the street where Miss Lucretia R. Tappan, later Mrs. Otis, lived before moving to England. It is mentioned as a point of reference for her social standing.
LOCATION.significance: Represents Mrs. Otis's past life and social status in America.

LOCATION.name: Ascot
LOCATION.description: Ascot is the nearest railway station to Canterville Chase. The Otis family arrives here and takes a waggonette to the castle. It is also mentioned as a location where the Duke of Cheshire and Mr. Otis go to search for Virginia.
LOCATION.significance: A point of entry to Canterville Chase and a location for the search for Virginia.

LOCATION.name: library
LOCATION.description: The library is a room within Canterville Chase. It is where the bloodstain is located and where the Otis family spends time. The ghost also makes appearances here.
LOCATION.significance: A key location where the ghost attempts to scare the family and where the bloodstain is a central plot element.

LOCATION.name: Tapestry Chamber
LOCATION.description: The Tapestry Chamber is a room within Canterville Chase. Virginia encounters the ghost here, and it is the location where she helps him find peace.
LOCATION.significance: The location where Virginia interacts with the ghost and helps him find peace.

LOCATION.name: Blue Bed Chamber
LOCATION.description: The Blue Bed Chamber is a room within Canterville Chase. It is where the twins reside and where the ghost attempts to scare them.
LOCATION.significance: A location where the ghost attempts to frighten the twins.

LOCATION.name: Brockley meadows
LOCATION.description: Brockley meadows is a meadow where Virginia and the Duke of Cheshire go riding. Virginia tears her habit here, and it is also where the gypsies are found.
LOCATION.significance: A location where Virginia is last seen before disappearing and where the gypsies are found.

LOCATION.name: Blackfell Hollow
LOCATION.description: Blackfell Hollow is a location where the gypsies are camped. Mr. Otis goes here to search for Virginia.
LOCATION.significance: A location where the gypsies are camped and where Mr. Otis searches for Virginia.

LOCATION.name: Bexley
LOCATION.description: Bexley is a village near Canterville Chase. Mr. Otis and the Duke of Cheshire go here to search for Virginia.
LOCATION.significance: A location where Mr. Otis and the Duke of Cheshire search for Virginia.

LOCATION.name: Red Farm
LOCATION.description: The Red Farm is a farm near Canterville Chase. The baying of a dog from the Red Farm is heard by the ghost.
LOCATION.significance: A minor location that provides background noise in the story.

LOCATION.name: Chertsey Barn
LOCATION.description: Chertsey Barn is a barn where the ghost impersonates the Corpse-Snatcher of Chertsey Barn.
LOCATION.significance: A location associated with one of the ghost's impersonations.

LOCATION.name: Hogley Woods
LOCATION.description: Hogley Woods is a woods where the ghost shot a buck.
LOCATION.significance: A location associated with the ghost's past.

LOCATION.name: Eton
LOCATION.description: Eton is a school where the young Duke of Cheshire is sent back to after proposing to Virginia.
LOCATION.significance: A location associated with the Duke of Cheshire's youth.

LOCATION.name: New York
LOCATION.description: New York is a city in the United States. Virginia suggests the ghost emigrate there.
LOCATION.significance: A location that represents a different culture and a potential new life for the ghost.

LOCATION.name: Garden of Death
LOCATION.description: The Garden of Death is a garden where the ghost wants to go to sleep.
LOCATION.significance: A symbolic location representing peace and rest for the ghost.

LOCATION.name: churchyard
LOCATION.description: The churchyard is where the ghost is buried. Virginia places flowers on his grave.
LOCATION.significance: The final resting place of the ghost and a symbol of his redemption.

LOCATION.name: St. George's, Hanover Square
LOCATION.description: St. George's, Hanover Square is a church where Virginia and the Duke of Cheshire are married.
LOCATION.significance: The location of Virginia's wedding.

LOCATION.name: Wales
LOCATION.description: Wales is a country where Lord Canterville comes from to attend the funeral.
LOCATION.significance: The origin of Lord Canterville.

LOCATION.name: London
LOCATION.description: London is a city in England. Lord Canterville takes the jewels to London.
LOCATION.significance: A location where Lord Canterville takes the jewels.

LOCATION.name: Wandsworth Common
LOCATION.description: Wandsworth Common is a common where Lord Canterville shot Jack Castleton in a duel.
LOCATION.significance: A location associated with the ghost's past.

LOCATION.name: Tunbridge Wells
LOCATION.description: Tunbridge Wells is a town where Lady Barbara died of a broken heart.
LOCATION.significance: A location associated with the ghost's past.

TIME_PERIOD.description: The year Lady Eleanore de Canterville was murdered by her husband, Sir Simon de Canterville.

TIME_PERIOD.name: Three centuries
TIME_PERIOD.description: The approximate time the ghost has been haunting Canterville Chase.
The year the ghost began making its appearances.

TIME_PERIOD.name: July
TIME_PERIOD.description: The month the Otis family moved into Canterville Chase.
The year Lady Startup saw the Vampire Monk and died.
The year the young Duchess of Cheshire was presented at the Queen's first drawing-room.

CONCEPT.name: The Ghost
CONCEPT.description: A spectral entity, Sir Simon de Canterville, bound to Canterville Chase. He attempts to scare the new residents, the Otis family, but his efforts are thwarted by their modern sensibilities and the twins' pranks. Ultimately, he seeks release from his haunting through Virginia's compassion and the fulfillment of an ancient prophecy.

CONCEPT.name: American Materialism vs. European Tradition
CONCEPT.description: The clash between the pragmatic, modern American values of the Otis family and the traditional, often superstitious, beliefs associated with the haunted Canterville Chase and its ghostly inhabitant. The Americans' lack of fear and their practical solutions to the ghost's antics highlight the contrast.

CONCEPT.name: Love and Forgiveness
CONCEPT.description: Virginia's compassion and willingness to help the ghost find peace. Her love and empathy for Sir Simon, and her role in fulfilling the prophecy, demonstrate the power of love to overcome death and sin. Forgiveness is a central theme, as Virginia's actions lead to the ghost's release and the blossoming of the almond tree.

CONCEPT.name: Death
CONCEPT.description: The concept of death is explored through the ghost's desire for rest and Virginia's understanding of its significance. The story suggests that death can be a release from suffering and a path to peace, and that love and forgiveness can play a role in the transition.

CONCEPT.name: The Prophecy
CONCEPT.description: The ancient verse from the library window, which foretells the conditions under which the ghost can find peace. The prophecy's fulfillment, through Virginia's actions, is central to the plot and symbolizes the triumph of love and forgiveness over sin and death.

CONCEPT.name: Supernatural
CONCEPT.description: The presence of the ghost and other paranormal events, such as the bloodstain that reappears, the mysterious noises, and the appearance of the spectral figure, create an atmosphere of mystery and suspense. The story explores the interaction between the living and the dead, and the possibility of life after death.

CONCEPT.name: Humor
CONCEPT.description: The story's humor arises from the contrast between the ghost's attempts to frighten the Otises and their reactions, which are often practical and dismissive. The twins' pranks and the Minister's matter-of-fact attitude contribute to the comedic effect, making the story a blend of mystery and wit.
